1.  Policies and Guidelines

It is the policy of the J.R. Simplot Company (Policy Statement EN 01.1) to manufacture, handle, store and dispose of all substances safely and in compliance with the requirements of federal, state and local environmental laws while reducing the risks to human health, safety and the environment. Each manager is expected to responsibly implement this policy, and each employee is expected to comply fully with the spirit, as well as the letter of this policy. The Company will assure that the environmental, health and safety laws, regulations, and standards applicable to its products and operations are known and obeyed by employees.

It is the policy of the Simplot AgriBusiness group, of the J.R. Simplot Company (Policy Statement M & C #3) that the processing, manufacturing, storage, shipping, or disposal of products and materials shall be carried out in a manner consistent with the protection of public safety and the environment, and in full conformity with the requirements of the law.

The J.R. Simplot Company Guideline (Guideline Statement SA 01.2) states that the Company is committed to reducing incidents or occurrences in the workplace that result in human injury, illness, or death, and/or destruction or loss to the corporation's assets and to be in compliance with all laws and regulations governing workplace safety. It is, therefore, our intent to provide a safe work environment and to protect the corporation's assets. This guideline applies to all groups and separate operating entities of the J.R. Simplot Company. Emergency plans shall be developed for each operating unit outlining the practices and procedures for emergency medical care, fire response, evacuation,

or other emergencies. Each group shall develop and implement appropriate programs for initial and ongoing safety and loss prevention training of employees.


2.  Regulated Substance(s)

The substance(s) that are routinely stored at this facility would be Anhydrous Ammonia at or above the threshold level for the RMP. 

Anhydrous Ammonia is received, stored and distributed to area fertilizer suppliers and/or farms as a source of land applied Nitrogen fertilizer, or could be distributed to industrial use customers. 

Maximum Quantity Stored at this site is 101,000,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia in two 9,708,738-gallon atmospheric storage tank(s). The maximum quantity handled would be 50,500,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia.  

4.  Accidental Release Program
         
This Anhydrous ammonia facility has implemented the provisions of Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia as published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI K61.1), and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.  

The Process Safety Management (PSM) program is one part of the comprehensive loss prevention and control system implemented at this facility. The implementation of PSM, Administrative Procedures, and Safe Work Practices represent the facility's main active elements of the accidental release prevention program.

5.  Five Year Accident History

One reportable incident has occurred in the last five years at the facility.     

On June 30, 2007 ammonia gas was released at the start of a ship off-load and caused employees at a neighboring facility to shelter in place.  The ammonia load arm had been connected to a ship, and liquid ammonia was being introduced into the load arm to cool it down before the off-load.  Liquid ammonia leaked out of a failed seal in a load arm swivel joint and evaporated.  The leak was discovered after about 15 minutes, and the

cool-down was then terminated.  According to witnesses, the release generated brief and mild odor on the Simplot side of the fence.  However, some employees at Evraz Oregon Steel, the neighboring facility to the north, experienced eye irritation, and about 80 employees left the production area and sheltered in place for about 90 minutes.  No recordable injuries were reported.  

As a result of this incident, the terminal emergency response plan was updated with a better emergency phone number for Evraz.  Also, additional maintenance is being conducted on the marine arm, even though existing maintenance frequencies and procedures met or exceeded manufacturer recommendations.  The additional maintenance procedure is to move the marine arm and swivel joints approximately every month. Fewer ammonia ships have visited the terminal in recent years than in the past, and one consideration is that long periods of inactivity could result in adhesion of the swivel joint seals to the sealing surfaces.  If the seals are adhered to the sealing surfaces, they can tear and cause leaks when the arm is moved.  Moving the joints on a more frequent basis will spread the lubricant around, and should prevent seal adhesion, tears, and leaks. 


6.  Emergency Response Program

This facility has developed a written emergency contingency plan (Integrated Contingency Plan). The plan addresses the regulations concerning emergency plans as mandated under: OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38, 1910.119, and 1910.120, EPA 40 CFR - part 264 subpart D, part 265 subpart D, part 68 and 279.52, DOT/RSPA-FRP - 49 CFR part 194, and 33CFR 127.  Elements within this plan include employee training, SARA Title III reporting requirements and community right to know, pre-emergency planning, and emergency response planning.

7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety and Environmental programs are very dynamic.  As this is an ongoing process, improvements are evaluated and implemented periodically. The need for improvement
is identified by facility employee inputs, inspections, incident investigations, and audits which are performed regularly at this facility.
